awd_titl_txt: Conference Title:  Improving STEM Teaching & Learning by Collaborations Between Cognitive Scientists and Discipline-Based Education Researchers
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a two-day working conference to be held at NSF headquarters in Arlington, VA, in spring 2016 to discuss ways of increasing collaborations between cognitive scientists and discipline-based education researchers. Working groups will discuss the three themes: (1) standards for evidence in cognitive science and discipline-based education research, (2) bridging the engineering of instructional solutions and innovations and attributing causality to those solutions and innovations; and (3) facilitating communication and collaboration across CS and DBER communities. The goal of the meeting is to discuss obstacles, opportunities, and policies that could be used as input in a national dialog to increase collaborations among CS and DBER
Researchers.

Despite advances in communication and occasional collaboration across these two fields, research from cognitive science that could be applied to improve teaching and learning in the STEM fields remains largely unknown to STEM scientists and discipline-based education researchers. Similarly, research-based instructional strategies in STEM remain largely unknown in the learning sciences. This meeting will convene key leaders from both fields for the purpose of discussing important methodological, practical, and philosophical issues in order to promote increased dialog and collaborations across the two communities.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the project were to plan and execute a conference to bring together cognitive psychologists (CogPsy) and discipline-based education researchers (DBER) in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education to discuss common interests and promote increased collaborations among these communities. The importance for promoting collaborations across these two communities hinges on the need to tackle increasingly complex problems in improving STEM education. DBER researchers work largely in the messy environment of classrooms, whereas CogPsy researchers work largely in lab settings with better-controlled learning experiments that try to tease apart cause-effect relationships. 

Such a conference was held at the headquarters of the National Science Foundation on September of 2017, and brought together 38 researchers from DBER and CogPsy who spent two days discussing ways of bridging the research methodologies and standards for evidence across DBER and CogPsy, as well as actions that would promote more collaborations across the two groups. A detailed final report emerged from the conference, titled “Maximizing undergraduate STEM learning: Promoting research at the intersection of cognitive psychology and discipline-based education research” that identified four core issues, namely: 1) Establishing the legitimacy of DBER/CogPsy collaborative work, 2) Promoting DBER-CogPsy collaborative work, 3) Enhancing communication between DBER and CogPsy, and 4) Uniting DBER scholars from different STEM disciplines. Recommendations associated with these four core issues were provided to the National Science Foundation in the final report. 

Two additional meetings were held following the initial conference. The first was held at Washington University in December of 2017 and brought together 6 teams of DBER-CogPsy collaborators to present their proposed collaborations and obtain formative feedback from the other attendees to help improve the projects. The last meeting was a national conference held at Washington University in September of 2018, which brought together over 90 DBER and CogPsy researchers to hear presentations of DBER-CogPsy research results and discuss additional avenues for collaboration.

Intellectual merit:  This project was an important first step in combining the expertise of the two diverse communities (CogSci and DBER) to understand barriers in student learning in STEM, to devise effective instructional interventions, and to evaluate why and how they are effective.

Broader impacts: A new national cohort of more than 90 DBER and CogPsy researchers have come together to explore collaborative opportunities in undergraduate STEM education.

Modified by: Jose P Mestre
